22772.meaning_2: destruction of the ridge; demolition of the peak
22772.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the quoted passage the term denotes the demolition of the roof‑peak, i.e., the destruction of the ridge that holds up all the rafters.
22772.sutta_1: “seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, kūṭāgārassa yā kāci gopānasiyo sabbā tā kūṭaṅgamā kūṭasamosaraṇā kūṭasamugghātā sabbā tā samugghātaṃ gacchanti;
22772.example_1: “Mendicants, the rafters of a bungalow all lean to the peak and meet at the peak, and when the peak is demolished they’re all demolished too.

10540.meaning_1: rooted in ignorance; stemming from not knowing
10540.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the given passage unskillful qualities are described as avijjāmūlaka, i.e., they originate from ignorance; the term captures the sense of being rooted in not‑knowing.
10540.sutta_1: evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye keci akusalā dhammā sabbe te avijjāmūlakā avijjāsamosaraṇā avijjāsamugghātā, sabbe te samugghātaṃ gacchanti.
10540.example_1: In the same way all unskillful qualities are rooted in ignorance and meet in ignorance, and when ignorance is demolished they’re all demolished too.

10549.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the passage the compound describes the tendency toward ignorance, i.e., the process of converging on delusion.
10549.sutta_1: evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye keci akusalā dhammā sabbe te avijjāmūlakā avijjāsamosaraṇā avijjāsamugghātā, sabbe te samugghātaṃ gacchanti.
10549.example_1: In the same way all unskillful qualities are rooted in ignorance and meet in ignorance, and when ignorance is demolished they’re all demolished too.

10546.meaning_1: eradication of ignorance; destruction of not understanding
10546.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the given passage (sn20.1:1.5) avijjāsamugghāta refers to the complete eradication of ignorance, i.e. the destruction of the state of not understanding.
10546.sutta_1: evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye keci akusalā dhammā sabbe te avijjāmūlakā avijjāsamosaraṇā avijjāsamugghātā, sabbe te samugghātaṃ gacchanti.
10546.example_1: In the same way all unskillful qualities are rooted in ignorance and meet in ignorance, and when ignorance is demolished they’re all demolished too.

32085.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the quoted passage the Dasārahas are referenced as a distinct people, similar to other group names like aṅgamagadhā.
32085.sutta_1: “bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, dasārahānaṃ ānako nāma mudiṅgo ahosi.
32085.example_1: “Once upon a time, mendicants, the Dasārahas had a mridangam drum called the Plugger.

31125.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In SN 20.8 the term refers to a cotton pillow, highlighting soft bedding used in the descriptive simile of the Licchavi women
31125.example_1: tesaṃ rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto na labhati otāraṃ na labhati ārammaṇaṃ. bhavissanti, bhikkhave, anāgatamaddhānaṃ licchavī sukhumālā [sukumālā, sukhumā] mudutalunahatthapādā [mudutalāhatthapādā] te mudukāsu seyyāsu tūlabimbohanāsu [tūlabimbohanāsu, tūlabimbohanādīsu, tūlabibbohanādīsu] yāvasūriyuggamanā seyyaṃ kappissanti. tesaṃ rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto lacchati otāraṃ lacchati ārammaṇaṃ.

31124.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In SN20.8 the word denotes cotton‑filled pillows, appearing in a list of future attainments.
31124.example_1: tesaṃ rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto na labhati otāraṃ na labhati ārammaṇaṃ. bhavissanti, bhikkhave, anāgatamaddhānaṃ licchavī sukhumālā [sukumālā, sukhumā] mudutalunahatthapādā [mudutalāhatthapādā] te mudukāsu seyyāsu tūlabimbohanāsu [tūlabimbohanāsu, tūlabimbohanādīsu, tūlabibbohanādīsu] yāvasūriyuggamanā seyyaṃ kappissanti. tesaṃ rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto lacchati otāraṃ lacchati ārammaṇaṃ.

54051.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the sentence it functions as an adverbial phrase meaning until sunrise, indicating the time up to which the sleeping continues.
54051.sutta_1: te mudukāsu seyyāsu tūlabibbohanāsu yāvasūriyuggamanā seyyaṃ kappissanti.
54051.example_1: They’ll sleep on soft beds with down pillows until the sun comes up.

45883.meaning_1: commentary on the Discourse on the Heap of Snares
45883.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In SN20.9 this term denotes the commentary on the Discourse on the Heap of Snares, explaining the consequences of actions and the Path.
45883.example_1: ni. 1 pāsarāsisuttavaṇṇanā oloketabbā] ādīnavadassāvino nissaraṇapaññā paribhuñjanti. tesaṃ taṃ vaṇṇāya ceva hoti balāya ca, na ca tatonidānaṃ maraṇaṃ vā nigacchanti maraṇamattaṃ vā dukkhaṃ.

62973.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the glossed sentence "yo ca sibbiyati sūcako hi so," sibbiyati means “is sewn/stretched,” describing the sūcako (thread) being sewn.
62973.sutta_1: yo ca sibbiyati sūcako hi so,

15123.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the given passage the word conveys the sense of “the teacher who was mentioned/pointed out”, reflecting its verbal root √uddis “to point up, indicate” in the context of “uddisita” meaning “acknowledged”.
15123.sutta_1: yatvāhaṃ, āvuso, kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito, nābhijānāmi aññaṃ satthāraṃ uddisitā, aññatra tena bhagavatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena.
15123.example_1: Since I shaved off my hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness, I don’t recall acknowledging any other teacher apart from the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.

43078.meaning_1: the Sutta on the ultimate death
43078.meaning_lit: the Sutta of the supreme death
43078.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
The term denotes a Saṃyutta Nikāya sutta concerning the concept of the ultimate or supreme death.

58056.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
The term denotes the Saṃyutta Nikāya discourse concerning the representation of faith, highlighting its role in spiritual practice.

18729.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In sn16.13 the verb opilavati describes something floating downstream, i.e., “floats down”, matching the literal meaning provided.
18729.example_1: The true teaching doesn’t disappear like a ship that sinks all at once.

18329.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the sentence, okkamaniyā qualifies "dhammā" as "detrimental" or "harmful", indicating five adverse teachings that cause decline.
18329.sutta_1: pañca khome, kassapa, okkamaniyā dhammā saddhammassa sammosāya antaradhānāya saṃvattanti.
18329.example_1: There are five detrimental things that lead to the decline and disappearance of the true teaching.

60934.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the passage “pañca khome … sammosāya antaradhānāya saṃvattanti,” sammosa refers to a cause of decline, i.e. forgetfulness or confusion that leads to the disappearance of the true teaching.
60934.sutta_1: pañca khome, kassapa, okkamaniyā dhammā saddhammassa sammosāya antaradhānāya saṃvattanti.
60934.example_1: There are five detrimental things that lead to the decline and disappearance of the true teaching.

3680.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In this context anantaradhāna denotes the uninterrupted continuity that sustains the true teaching.
3680.sutta_1: pañca khome, kassapa, dhammā saddhammassa ṭhitiyā asammosāya anantaradhānāya saṃvattanti.
3680.example_1: There are five things that lead to the continuation, persistence, and enduring of the true teaching.

43077.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the phrase “cīvaraṃ paraṃmaraṇaṃ,” the compound denotes the ultimate or final death, i.e., the last passing away of the body.

32351.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In SN 17.1 it labels a discourse on harsh or severe teachings, i.e., a "severe sutta" within the Lābha‑sakkāra collection.

48231.meaning_1: discourse on youth; sutta for young bhikkhus
48231.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
The term refers to the Saṃyutta Nikāya sutta concerning young bhikkhus; it is a neuter compound formed by baḷisa young + sutta discourse.

22492.comment:

In SN 17.3 the term kummasuttaṃ appears as part of the compound lābhasakkārasaṃyuttaṃ, referring to a bundle or cluster of threads, i.e., a gathered set.

32768.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
Refers to a discourse on long‑haired ascetics in the Saṃyutta Nikāya (SN 17.4).

18239.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the sentence “dīghalomikā eḷakā … paviseyya”, eḷakā denotes a sheep, i.e., a woolly animal, illustrating the imagined scenario of a sheep entering a thicket.
18239.sutta_1: seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, dīghalomikā eḷakā kaṇṭakagahanaṃ paviseyya.
18239.example_1: Suppose a fleecy sheep was to enter a briar patch.

52751.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
Fifth sutta of the Saṃyutta Nikāya 17, titled “Mīḷhakasutta”, referring to that specific discourse.

9425.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
Asanisutta is the title of a Saṃyutta Nikāya discourse concerning the seat (āsana).

32576.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In Saṃyutta Nikāya 17 the term denotes the “perfected sutta”, a discourse considered complete or perfected.

61166.meaning_1: (any sharp pointed object which causes pain) arrow; spike; dagger; dart; barb
61166.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the cited context "sallanti" uses "salla" metaphorically for "arrow" representing possessions, honor and popularity.
61166.example_1: ‘Arrow’ is a term for possessions, honor, and popularity.

62824.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
The Siṅgāla Sutta (SN 17.8) is a discourse addressed to the young layman Siṅgāla, discussing proper conduct and social etiquette.

14001.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the cited passage the term denotes an elderly person, used as a variant of “ukkaṇḍaka”, i.e. “old man”.
14001.example_1: evaṃ, bhante. eso kho, bhikkhave, jarasiṅgālo ukkaṇḍakena  [ukkaṇḍakena, ukkaṇṇakena] nāma rogajātena phuṭṭho neva bilagato ramati, na rukkhamūlagato ramati, na ajjhokāsagato ramati, yena yena gacchati, yattha yattha tiṭṭhati, yattha yattha nisīdati, yattha yattha nipajjati, tattha tattha anayabyasanaṃ āpajjati. evameva kho, bhikkhave, idhekacco bhikkhu lābhasakkārasilokena abhibhūto pariyādiṇṇacitto neva suññāgāragato ramati, na rukkhamūlagato ramati, na ajjhokāsagato ramati, yena yena gacchati, yattha yattha tiṭṭhati, yattha yattha nisīdati, yattha yattha nipajjati, tattha tattha anayabyasanaṃ āpajjati.

1405.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
The term describes the jackal's lack of happiness in his den, i.e., he is not pleased in the inner part.
1405.sutta_1: “eso kho, bhikkhave, jarasiṅgālo ukkaṇḍakena nāma rogajātena phuṭṭho neva bilagato ramati, na rukkhamūlagato ramati, na ajjhokāsagato ramati;
1405.example_1: “That old jackal has the disease called mange. He’s not happy in his den, or at the root of a tree, or out in the open.

70440.comment:

Verambhasutta is a Saṃyutta Nikāya 17 discourse that uses the term verambha (hollow) as a metaphor for emptiness, often linked to meditative reflections on non‑self.

56540.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In SN 17.10 this is the tenth sutta of the Lābha Saṃyutta, titled “Sagāthaka Sutta,” i.e., a discourse that contains verses.

64558.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In SN 17.11 this sutta belongs to the Lābha‑sakkāra collection and presents a discourse on gold (suvaṇṇa), explaining its compound formation.

55318.meaning_1: the Sutta on rūpiya (the doctrine of form)

In SN 17.12 the term refers to the sutta titled “Rūpiyapātisutta”, i.e., the discourse on rūpiya, a discussion of the nature of form.

64552.comment:

In SN 17.12 this neuter compound designates the “golden‑sutta division”, a sub‑section of the Saṃyutta Nikāya that deals with discourses on gold.

52219.comment:

20696.comment:

In SN 17.14 the term refers to the Sutta called Kalyāṇī, i.e. a well‑spoken discourse within the Saṃyutta Nikāya.

17593.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
The term refers to the single discourse on "the one thing"; "ekaputtaka" compounds "eka" (one) with "puttaka" (thing), and the whole is the name of a Saṃyutta Nikāya 17 sutta.

12258.comment:

12258.example_1: A faithful laywoman with a dear and beloved only son would rightly appeal to him,

This is the fourth sutta in the Lābha‑sakkāra group of the Saṃyutta Nikāya, discussing the discourse on a single‑element theme.

27553.comment:

Appears in SN 17.21 as a designated sutta, likely a discourse on royal conduct.

49987.comment:

The term denotes a specific sutta in the Saṃyutta Nikāya; its literal meaning relates to a bean‑related discourse, though the exact etymology is uncertain.

49983.comment:

In the given context, “bhindi” functions as a verb form meaning “breaks” or “shatters”, describing Devadatta’s mind being overwhelmed; it derives from the root √bhid “to break”.

In SN 17.24 the term denotes the sutta that discusses skillful roots.

63416.comment:

In SN 17.26 this term denotes the sutta that expounds the pleasant Dhamma, emphasizing its wholesome qualities.

In SN 17.27 this denotes the sutta titled “Acirapakkanta”, discussing the ending of the early period.

2548.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the passage attavadhāya indicates the self-destruction that brings about Devadatta loss.

2548.example_1: “Possessions, honor, and popularity came to Devadatta for his own ruin and downfall.

39869.comment:

Refers to a Sutta in the Saṃyutta Nikāya concerning the five objects; the compound is formed from “pañcara” (five), “artha” (object) and “sutta” (discourse).

46310.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the sentence “mā, bhikkhave, devadattassa lābhasakkārasilokaṃ pihayittha,” the aorist form “pihayi” conveys the imperative sense of “do not envy” or “refrain from coveting,” reflecting a moral admonition against jealousy.

46122.comment:

The term denotes the discourse on the eye, appearing in the Saṃyutta Nikāya.

55259.comment:

Refers to the Saṃyutta Nikāya sutta on form (rūpa) addressed to Rāhula, i.e., a discourse concerning the nature of form.

60526.comment:

The entry refers to Sutta No.4 of the Saṃyutta Nikāya 18, titled samphassa sutta, a discourse on perception.

57441.comment:

In SN 18.6 the term refers to the sutta that explains the teaching on perception, a key discourse for understanding mental constructs.

57299.comment:

6047.comment:

1892.comment:
